labels.name: blocking next
labels.description: Something that needs fixing before the next version

labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: discuss
labels.description: We need some consensus amongst the authors how/wether to address the issue

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

labels.name: has PR
labels.description: There is a PR that will likely close the issue

issues.title: Do we want to differentiate DNS64 vs local synthesis cases?
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
I think it might be useful to test with RFC8781 w/o DNS64 as a primary case and maybe have a separate case (?) for DNS64 presence?
It would be desirable to ensure that there are no dependencies on DNS64?

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
As part of a section on name resolution issues to look for, that makes very much sense.

@furry13 ideas who may want to contribute a section on that?

comments.author: furry13
comments.body: We might want to have a 'network topologies' section

issues.title: CLAT case needs to be mentioned explicitly?
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: When "IPv6-only + NAT64" client is tested, do we want to ensure that the OS doesn't have CLAT enabled, so I guess it's worth mentioning explicitly

comments.author: mstojens
comments.body: I think so. If the terms are split, fine. If not, I suggest renaming this term "IPv6-mostly" rather than mention NAT64 specifically in the term itself (the definition of course is fine).

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
Makes sense to clarify that we want no CLAT for testing as it is covered in Dual-Stack or IPv4 only.

I also thought about mentioning IPv6-mostly initially, but in the end, IPv6-mostly is from a client perspective either dual-stack (464XLAT, no option 108 so native v4) or IPv6-only (with IPv6 or IPv4 behind NAT64). So I focus on NAT64 as everything else is covered in Dual-Stack or IPv4-only.

issues.title: Rename "unlikely" category
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
The current text says:

"The other combinations are unlikely to exhibit additional problems and therefore are marked as unlikely"

IMHO it's. bit optimistic, and might send a wrong message that it needs to be tested.
 I'd rather move them to 'basic' category (or maybe renaming all cstegories)

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body: This is definitely a trade-off. I am happy to rename it to _extended_ and make it sound a little less optional, but having a too large basic set will reduce probability testing is done at all. For our Zoo, I have not seen a single application that had a Problem on in these scenarios. Mayme it makes sense to batch that with STUN/TURN and mention that these cases definitely need checking the extended set.

issues.title: Explicitly mention MTU/fragmentation testing
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: as IPv4/IPv6/NAT64 networks might exhibit different behaviours, it would be nice to mention it

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
Cases:

1. MTU in RA == 1280
2. Router uplink with MTU=1280 and MTU in RA == 1500

issues.title: STUN/TURN cases
issues.author: furry13
issues.body: IF STUN/TURN is involved, it might be needed to test more cases (all combinations with clients + all combinations of servers)

issues.title: Definition: "IPv[46] Connectivity
issues.author: furry13
issues.body:
As it was discussed at v6ops during Ondrej presentation, we might want to have a standard definition of "connectivity".

Default gateway? non-link-local IPs?

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
That's a hard one… for this document, I'm quite tempted to explicitly define that as out-of-scope.
It gets really confusing to get that one right if you can have partial IPv6 and Partial IPv4 connectivity over multiple links/VPNs and each resource may or may not be available over random subsets of these either for address family, routing, and policy reason.

comments.author: furry13
comments.body:
We can say sm th like 'in the vast majority of cases it is sufficient to have a default route". However some apps might require testing more specific routes.

?? Do we want to consider CLAT as 'IPV4 connectivity'?

issues.title: Warn against VPNs like Apple Private Relay
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body: Explain how this can screw IPv6 only testing

issues.title: Add/Mention customer support perspective
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> I think the introduction might want to say more about how this document might
interact with diagnosis of end-customer problems.  With the view to avoiding
the "Just turn off IPv6" that comes from many places, and which might just
result in confused tech-support when there winds up being no connectivity :-)

issues.title: Add considerations for proxies and other application layer mechanisms to Section 4
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
We already have the Apple Private relay stuff in Sec. 4.1, but that needs more generalization & explanation

From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> When you write *proxy*, there are SOCKS and HTTP proxies and other
application layer mechanisms (ultimately: SMTP "bridged" by UUCP[%]...), which
might be reachable over one protocol, and then provide connectivity of a different
kind.   The combinatorics here are large.   In particular, the connectivity
of the proxy itself can go all through all the combinations Table 1!

issues.title: Reference RFC8520 in Section 6.2?
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> Section 6.2 might want to reference MUD, RFC8520.

issues.title: Discuss broken DNS A/AAAA scenarios
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> if prune the A RR is a method, then they
may also need to insert phony/broken AAAA RRs, and then one has to worry
about permutting the order of RR returned.

This can also happen through mis-configured DNS servers, "DNS security appliances” or miscommunication between DNS and LB teams… Maybe add as scenario for Section 5

issues.title: Fix/broaden perspective of test scenarios
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
From Michael Richardson's early review on -00:
> Maybe there are a few new sections needed for:
> 1. residential IoT
> 2. on-premise services and appliances.
> 2b.  a subset of this would include Enterprise IoT.
> 2c.  I think of routing/switching infrastructure as being the original IoT,
    or, maybe, "Things of Internet"... because how does your XYZ vendor
    routing platform call v4-home to validate licenses or update firmware
    when there is no v4?
> 3. Among the v6-only, but-not-v6-global, would include SNAC.
  Right now, this mechanism is focused on low-speed, challenged STUB
  Networks.   However, one interesting way to deploy a cluster of systems
  (could even be entirely virtual) to an Enterprise would be with a v6-only
  STUB network.

comments.author: philsbln
comments.body:
partially addressed in #17 in a very abstract way.

Do we want to address such scenarios explicitly or is it okay to just have an abstract enough definition including these scenarios?

issues.title: Add Subsection on testing broken connectivity scenarios (DS with broken v4/v6, DNS filtering,…)
issues.author: philsbln

issues.title: Discuss testing with DNS vs. with IPv4/IPv6 literals
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
@kouellette brought up whether it would be worthwhile to add a short sub-section either here or elsewhere in the document regarding the use of IP literals rather than FQDNs. 

We should either add this to section 2.

issues.title: Include VPN / DNS split-brain connectivity pronblem?
issues.author: philsbln
issues.body:
Nick discussed a VPN / DNS split-brain problem in the latest episode of the IPv6 Buzz.

It's basically Partial v4/v6 connectivity (e.g., IPv6-only Internet with NAT64, but some IPv6 over VPN or the other way around).
In these cases, the resolver gets nuts and filters out everything of the address family despite it would have connectivity for a few endpoints.

Is it to special?
It's nothing he application can do about it except implementing Happy Eyeballs and hope that irons out some of these cases.

If we decide to include it… rather put it in Section [3.3. Testing with Partially Broken Connectivity](https://philsbln.github.io/ipv6-app-testing/draft-tiesel-v6ops-ipv6-app-testing.html#name-testing-with-partially-brok) or [5.2 Destination Address Selection Preference and Address Filtering](https://philsbln.github.io/ipv6-app-testing/draft-tiesel-v6ops-ipv6-app-testing.html#name-destination-address-selecti)?

issues.title: Discuss testing without 127.0.0.0/8 available
issues.author: spmzt
issues.body:
I think we should test applications to work without the 127.0.0.0/8 range available.
This is a real problem for us in production. For example, in FreeBSD there is an option to assign IPv4 and IPv6 stacks in a jail and when operating in an IPv6-only environment you don't want to assign the IPv4 stack. For many basic services we use (for example, BIND or Nginx) we must change the default configuration to replace 127.0.0.1 with ::1 to make them work.

comments.author: tojens-ietf
comments.body: +1, as I have seen apps using addresses across the 127.0.0.0/8 space (not just 127.0.0.1) as a presumed constantly-available resource to achieve inter-process communication between processes of the same "app"

issues.title: Diversify the source of IPv6 mandates, market forces, and deployment requirements
issues.author: tojens-ietf
issues.body: Right now the Introduction solely relies on U.S. OMB M-21-07, which is indeed a strong force driving IPv6 adoption and compat requirements in the U.S. but it's not globally inclusive, and the U.S. isn't the only source of similar mandates. It would be good to mention market forces also, like the unequal access to IPv4 space between developing versus developed countries, Global South versus Global North, etc. (not to say use these terms, just that aside from mandates there are many places where IPv6-only is a reality of life)

Other than those suggestions, looks good to me.


reviews.author: philsbln
reviews.body: I would suggest to separate definition (moving them up to section 2) and recommendations (keeping them in section 3). Otherwise, I like the addition.

comments.body: We should consider moving these definitions as well as the Reference to Section 2 and only keep the Lifecycle Function Testing Considerations in Section 3

I would like to separate definition and recommendation here
```suggestion
Orthogonal to the Base Scenarios, we define lifecycle functions, i.e., the phases in which an application is approached during a simplified lifecycle of the application, in accordance to [NIST.SP.500-267Ar1] as follows:
```

Text moved down and merged as suggested above…
```suggestion
## Testing Lifecycle Function Considerations

To cover the whole lifecycle of an application including installation, user interface,
management, and update, it is recommended to test that the lifecycle functions defined in {{lifecycle-functions}} are operational within the connectivity scenarios defined in {{scn_combinations}}.

In particular keep the following considerations in mind:
```

pulls.title: Collection of knits to fix for -01
pulls.author: philsbln
pulls.body:
- Split-VPN resolver problem (closes #23)
- Fixes one sentence in Section 3.3
- Update ref I-D.draft-winters-v6ops-rfc7084bis -> I-D.draft-ietf-v6ops-rfc7084bis:

comments.body:
```suggestion
- Some resolvers ignore address families for which no default route exists or where the default-route is pointing to an unsupported/ignored device.
```

```suggestion
While the IETF does not define compliance tests, best current practice exists for the behavior of general IPv6 nodes [RFC8504] and Customer Edge (CE) routers [I-D.draft-ietf-v6ops-rfc7084bis].
```
Looks like RFC8405 is more IGP related than general IPv6 node related :)

```suggestion
  RFC8504:
```

Actually, since node requirements is also going through an update in 6man, do we want to link to that (I-D.draft-ietf-6man-rfc8504-bis) instead? I'm not sure what the standard practice is as far as referencing other ongoing drafts...
good catch – thank you!

reviews.author: tojens-ietf
reviews.body: Thank you for doing this! I suggested a sentence order change that makes sense to me, but it isn't blocking.

comments.body:
```suggestion
This target has changed in part due to a series of national regulations mandating state entities to proceed in the migration to IPv6, e.g., in
```

Swapping the sentence structure made this easier to understand for me, YMMV.

Sorry for the three part edit. Making multiline suggestions on a touchscreen is interesting.

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
China [CAC-2023], the United States of America [US-OMB-M-21-07], Germany [DE-BIT-2020-14], and the Czech Republic [CZ-ENDv4].
```
